Look, you know, again, I go back to the Reagan, we don't tell them -- they don't tell us how to cover the news, we won't tell you how to run the White House. We've talked plenty about the Trump economy and often put up stats to show how much it has improved from January 2017 until May of 2019.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Yes. And, of course the president has --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.utterance: But I'm glad the president watches.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Yes. And he did sit down with you at least once. Chris Wallace, good luck tonight. Great to see you from New Hampshire. Thanks very much.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.utterance: Thanks, Howie.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: I'll be watching tonight. After the break, Beto O'Rourke says that glitzy Vanity Fair cover was a mistake. Why his media honeymoon faded fast. And later, Howard Stern is trying to change his raunchy image with a new book.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: From the campaign trail to his Twitter feed, President Trump has been aiming his fire at just one of the 23 Democratic candidates, and each time reporters ask Joe Biden for his response which in turn kicks off the next news cycle.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: I don't know what the hell happened to Biden. What happened to him? I'm looking, I said that doesn't look like the guy I knew. What happened to him? And Bernie, you know, Bernie's crazy.

utterances.speaker: FMR. VICE PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to get down in the mud wrestling with him. I'm not going to stoop to his level. I'm not going to engage in the name-calling.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Joining us now, Susan Ferrechio, chief congressional correspondent for the Washington Examiner. So, the New York Times reports unnamed Trump advisers are telling the president they wish he'd stop slamming Biden because it just elevates him in the Democratic race. He's not listening, so they leak it. Are the media, though, following Trump's lead in basically treating this as a two-man race?

utterances.speaker: SUSAN FERRECHIO, CHIEF CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT, WASHINGTON EXAMINER
utterances.utterance: Well, they see it as a two-man race. Because Biden is ahead not just nationally by double digits but in the key races that lead you to getting the Democratic nomination. So, he's winning on both those fronts.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: But it's so early.

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: Well, it is so early, that's true. But it looks pretty good, though, you have to admit. He's the dominant candidate, eight years as vice president from a very popular president, President Obama's administration. He has clear advantages right now.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: I do more than admit it, I have been saying this for months, and there was such a drum beat from the media, he's going to be a terrible candidate, he's too old, he's not liberal enough, he gets in the race. And now, three weeks later, Reuters has a lead, it says, can anyone stop Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: And if you look at the pre-polling, he was ahead all the time.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: I mean, I think it looked that way from the beginning, frankly.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: But I think the media have trouble dealing with 23 candidates and they kind of want to nail it down to at least a few because fewer characters makes for a better narrative.

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: That's true, but I also think this whole thread with President Trump stems from the fact that the president knows that Biden is going to be the candidate he's running against, and those labels worked for him. He did it with that little Marco, lying Ted, and all.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: But he runs the risk of actually helping Biden win the nomination by defining him as the leading candidate, as the nominee.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: So, he's really, he's winning and losing by using the labeling.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: All right. Candidate number 23, New York Mayor Bill de Blasio got into the race this week. Here he is with George Stephanopoulos.

utterances.speaker: GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS, CHIEF ANCHOR, ABC NEWS
utterances.utterance: Quinnipiac poll showed 76 percent of New York voters, 73 percent of New York Democrats say you shouldn't run, so what should the rest of the country think when so many of your fellow New Yorkers saying don't run?

utterances.speaker: MAYOR BILL DE BLASIO (D-NY), PRESIDENTIAL CANDAIDATE
utterances.utterance: The poll that actually matters is the election.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: So, I don't quite get why Bill de Blasio is running. But there's been so much media mockery from the New York Post and others. You would think he was the mayor of South Bend instead of New York.

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: You have to go back and see that the media, local media in New York and Bill de Blasio have never gotten along, especially the New York Post which I believe he said shouldn't exist at some point.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: Some kind of real insult against the paper. Not surprised to see that adverse relationship. But the general media in New York has not gotten along well with De Blasio. He's not treated him well.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Yes. He doesn't play with them.

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: He's been arrogant. That's right.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: He doesn't give them a schedule.

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: But the public has also criticized him for not fixing the transit system in New York, the homeless problem increasing and all these other issues, exaggerating his record. But he is very progressive. He fits the mold of all these candidates who are running, so --

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: I mean, he did get elected twice but there are all these other candidates. And Beto O'Rourke, I want to play this sound bite where he talks about the launching his campaign with that Vanity Fair cover.

utterances.speaker: JOY BEHAR, HOST, ABC
utterances.utterance: Would you say those are mistakes, being on the cover of Vanity Fair? This.

utterances.speaker: FMR. REP. BETO O'ROURKE (D-TX), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Yes, So --

utterances.speaker: BEHAR
utterances.utterance: Yes. It looks elitist, what?

utterances.speaker: O'ROURKE
utterances.utterance: Yes. I think it reinforces that perception of privilege. And that the headline that said I was born to be in this, in the article I was attempting to say that I felt that my calling was in public service.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: So, Vanity Fair was a mistake, the Springsteen line born to run, that was a mistake. By the way, the editor says he said it, it was not taken out of context, the editor of Vanity Fair. boy, the media pretty quickly fell out of love with this guy.

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: And I think the simple of reason he was a lot of flash, a lot of style but not a lot of substance, and I think the video, filming himself, you know, getting his dental cleaning and ear hairs, whatever --

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: There's a new one, let's put up the haircut video, because America wants to see this. Yes, are you excited?

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: There's the haircut, right? So he's doing all these things, he's trying to invite the public in to see his life, but I think the public is looking for a more serious candidate like the one you were just talking about with Chris Wallace, candidate Buttigieg, who's a small town mayor, comes out very earnest, has a campaign platform he can talk about.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: I think that's the big difference. Not the Vanity Fair cover. He could have used that to launch a very successful campaign, he just didn't have a lot to follow along with it.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean, he's got an interesting personal story, but once you've told that a few times he hasn't seen so far have much to say beyond platitudes. We'll see if that changes. Susan Ferrechio, great to see you.

utterances.speaker: FERRECHIO
utterances.utterance: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Thanks so much. Still to come, the king of all media now does lengthy, intimate interviews with celebrities. What happened to Howard Stern?

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Howard Stern is out with a bestselling book that chronicles his transformation from raunchy shock jock to a Sirius XM host was long, thoughtful, provocative interviews, the likes of Anderson Cooper, Katie Couric, Conan O'Brien, Paul McCartney, and he's on the circuit promoting Howard Stern comes again which includes his old interviews with Donald Trump, celebrity businessman.

utterances.speaker: HOWARD STERN, RADIO HOST
utterances.utterance: I was quite surprised when they dragged out every single Donald Trump the interview I had done. And in some ways, I felt it was unfair to Trump.

utterances.speaker: STEPHANOPOULOS
utterances.utterance: Do you feel that in some way you helped make him president?

utterances.speaker: STERN
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. Because Donald would come on my show -- I mean, look --

utterances.speaker: STEPHANOPOULOS
utterances.utterance: Does it make you feel bad or good?

utterances.speaker: STERN
utterances.utterance: Well, look, I did not vote for Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Joining us now, Emily Jashinsky, culture editor of The Federalist. And Stern makes no bones about the fact while he loved all the locker room talk and all those interviews with Donald Trump who rated women and did a lot of other things, he was a big Hillary Clinton supporter and wanted to get her on in, and of course, she wouldn't do the show.

utterances.speaker: EMILY JASHINSKY, CULTURE EDITOR, THE FEDERALIST
utterances.utterance: There's an entire chapter in his book called "Hillary Clinton, The Interview That Never Happened," where he makes the case that had Hillary Clinton done his show there could have been, you know, contractors, store owners, truck drivers that heard her in swing states, Wisconsin, Ohio, and Pennsylvania and were really impressed and it might have changed the election. He literally says that. He makes the case in this whole chapter. It's very interesting.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Yes. He's still stunned, I think, that he became a kind of a factor in the campaign because everybody was going to the archives we're playing. Now here he is with Stephanopoulos on GMA having a little fun at George's expense.

utterances.speaker: STERN
utterances.utterance: Inevitably, Ali will go, George and I have sex every night. I'm like -- and George sits there, George doesn't laugh. I never think of you as a sex thing, but I'm like -- I said did you -- I said can you picture George and Ali every night?

utterances.speaker: STEPHANOPOULOS
utterances.utterance: Completely hijacked, right here.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Ali Wentworth is George's wife. Any sympathy for George there?

utterances.speaker: JASHINSKY
utterances.utterance: Well, look how uncomfortable he made Stephanopoulos, and that's where like, this book does chronicle a gradual transformation and significant transformation, but that's not to say that the old Howard Stern is totally gone forever.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: Yes. Yes, sex comes up now and then.

utterances.speaker: JASHINSKY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: But you know, people who knew only the old Howard Stern from trustable radio would be stunned because, you know, he will spend an hour, an hour and a half with these celebrities.

utterances.speaker: JASHINSKY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: And they have this sort of dinner party conversations and he has of drawing that. For example, I remember listening to Anderson Cooper with Howard, very revealing talk about when he was closeted for all those the years as a television anchor, coming out, how he got out of the teenage modeling business at the age of 13 because a man had propositioned him and stuff, you wouldn't get in a traditional interview.

utterances.speaker: JASHINSKY
utterances.utterance: No, absolutely not.
